instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2849: What is 820-2849? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
Ok guys. My first problem to post and I hope you will be able to help with this.

This is a 2010 Macbook Pro 17" that I purchased from a someone this week. Sold as 'not charging, tried 2 different chargers' and I took the chance on the basis they probably did not know you had to use an 85w magsafe. Anyway, got it, plugged in and green light straight away which is always nice. Battery is no good, so cannot tell about charging as such yet. Have checked both current sensing circuits for DC in and battery, both check out fine.

On removing rear cover I immediately honed in on two red flags. One, the fans were spotless. Two, flux around <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>. Someone has been telling uncle Jimmy porkies!!!!! Clean fans usually means someon has been in and doing something, albeit just cleaning someone has been in here first which I hate.

So, to the problem so far. Have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 8.4v. Have pp3v42 obviously and needless to say DC in etc. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> at C75205 was coming up at 0.7v.

Straight to that <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> for a closer look and although it seems to be the original (no tweeer marks) and seemed to soldered well, replaced it as a matter of course. Whilst it was removed I measured pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7901</RESISTOR> for EN signal and got a nice steady 3.3v as hoped. On fitting <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> that dropped to 2.4v. Replaced <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> again just to be sure chip wasn't bad and got exact same result.

Pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C7205</CAPACITOR> is showing 0.772v with both the new chips.

A little bit baffled by this one. Racking my brains so ANY pointers will be gratefully received.

Thanks
Jimmy

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message: Post resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and both output coils L7220/60.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
Resistance to ground <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> at pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C7205</CAPACITOR> is 40K Ohm
L7260 is 610 Ohms
L7220 is jumping all over the place between 7M Ohm and 20K, never settling on multimeter,. Goes down from 7M to 212K to 20k, back to 94k etc etc, My meter is not the best, but good enough VC97 - not dissimilar to Fluke 15B.

I shgould correct something. Voltage at Pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C7205</CAPACITOR> is 0.772v, not 2.4 as I said in my original post - sorry.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
We normally expect measuring on diode mode at power rails.
Post L7260 values on diode mode; red to ground and black to ground too.

200ohm scale is useful to distinquish lower values.
200k-20M is useful to check some signals also.

BTW, no power on board for such kind of measuring...

Next, post voltages at <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>, pins 12, 22, 23.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
Thanks for your help so far.

My multimeter is a VC97+. It is alright but not as advanced as the ones I suspect you use. I can read in diode mode, but only have two options. If I opt for sound (short to ground etc) I get JUST that, sound or nothing but no ohms . If I measure without sound it displays only in volts. Does that sound correct?. So, that in mind here we go:

And yes, I do measure resistance/diode mode with power off.

L7260 is showing 0.5v in diode mode on my (crapo) multimeter
L7220 is showing 0.4v in diode mode on my (crapo crap crap) multimeter

<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>:
Pin 12 is showing 2.7v
Pin 22 is showing 3.0mV
Pin 22 is showing 7.2v

Just been reading the online manual for my multimeter and it seems that in diode mode it measures the forward voltage of a diode. I'd probably be better off using an empty coke bottle!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
"My [URL="http://amzn.to/2jnkPIx"]multimeter[/URL] is a VC97+. It is alright but not as advanced as the ones I suspect you use."
I prefer a manual range one, for less than 15$.
When I use auto-range model, I will manually select the range.
No need of Fluke, or other expensive multimeters.

"Pin 22 is showing 3.0mV
Pin 22 is showing 7.2v"
Mmmmhhhhh...

BTW, are you using original Apple charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
100% original. I learned my lesson many macs back.

I initially test all macbooks using my digital power supply until I know nothing too dramatic will happen, then swicth to the original magsafe 85w for certainty.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
"Have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 8.4v
pin 23 is 7.2v"
???

<CHIP>U7201</CHIP> should work even with 6V, but I have no idea why you get different values in the same rail.
Check diode mode at pin 22 too.
Diode mode should be "no buzz mode".

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
Sorry for confusion. When I checked the board yesterday it was showing 8.4v on G3H. When I tested pin 23 of <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> today it was 7.2v. I didn't check the same place on the other siwde of the board today, just what you asked for. I am sure it will be the same obviously/

In the morning I will check it properly and upload all the readings.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
Good morning everyone

This board actually got to me during the night. See if you can follow my line of thought here.

The mac had obviously been worked on by someone before as there was flux around <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and perhaps I should have walked away on seeing that. But like most of us I get a huge buzz if I can fix a board, especially those ones.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is the same (7.2v this morning) wherever I check it, which would not make any sense otherwise, so you are quite right to question the different figures that I hope I explained in my previous post. But what has got to me is the low voltage (near enough zero) on pin 22 of <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>. That connects to <CAPACITOR>C7203</CAPACITOR>. If that was shorted to ground, that would explain something so I removed it to check. Pin 2 of <CAPACITOR>C7203</CAPACITOR> is supposed to be ground, pin 1 is not. But pin 1 solder point (with cap removed) is shorted to ground. Mmmmmm... Now I am on to something me thinks....

Pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C7203</CAPACITOR> goes to pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7248</RESISTOR>. Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7248</RESISTOR> goes to Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7249</RESISTOR>, which in turn pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7249</RESISTOR> goes to ground - a voltage divider if I am not mistaken. Problem is <RESISTOR>R7248</RESISTOR> is shorted to ground on both pins, so is <RESISTOR>R7249</RESISTOR>. What the.......? No wonder Pin 22 of <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> is showing next to nothing!

NOW. Looking at the schematic and I think there is one of Apple's printing errors. Can anyone confirm if it is just me, but <RESISTOR>R7248</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7249</RESISTOR> are both listed as zero ohm? Effectively shorting straight to ground.

I am just wondering if the previous person to attack this board replaced the originals with zero ohms because the schematic says so? Obviously the originals would have been correct. Two zero ohm resistors in sieries is not an voltage divider, but the techical term I believe is 'a wire'.

Am I losing my mind, or have I found a bit of a problem?

So, if anyone can have a look at their schematic and tell me what <RESISTOR>R7248</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7249</RESISTOR> should actually be or an educated guess what be good so I can replace those two, eliminate the short on <CAPACITOR>C7203</CAPACITOR> and hopefully we can restore life into this old mac after all?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
Good enough to use other MacBook schematic with <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP>.
Some Apple schematics have been found on Internet with printing error...

Remove <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and check if short gone.
Be aware, do NOT power up the board without <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
Thanks again for your input.

I did check with <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> removed, short gone. But struggling to confirm if that actually is a voltage divider and if so what restances should be used. Got lots of schematics, but thje only ones that also show TPS51980a show the same 2 zero ohm resistors.

With <CAPACITOR>C7203</CAPACITOR>, <RESISTOR>R7248</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R7249</RESISTOR> removed but <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> re-soldered, voltages as follows:

<CHIP>U7201</CHIP> pin 22 is 0.770v
<CHIP>U7201</CHIP> pin 23 is 7.45v
<CHIP>U7201</CHIP> pin 12 is 3.76v

<CAPACITOR>C7205</CAPACITOR> is 0.504v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
Don't remove anything!
Check for shorts with all pieces in place.
And post again the values after that.

BTW, you still have a problem with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
So remove F7040/41 and post voltage at <CAPACITOR>C7040</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message: Pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C7040</CAPACITOR> is 9.7v with f7040 an f7041 removed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
Put F7040 and F7041 back on. getting 8.4v at L7031 pin 2 and the same at pin 23 of <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>

the one part I am confused over is the two resistors <RESISTOR>R7248</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7249</RESISTOR>. can anyone confirm what they should be please?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
Be aware of "NO STUFF" marking in schematic.
In your case, means <RESISTOR>R7248</RESISTOR> is not soldered; only <RESISTOR>R7249</RESISTOR> is in place.
If you put both, will short VREG3 to ground...

8.4V is correct for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> if machine has 2 cells battery.
Replace <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> with new and pay atention to solder perfectly all its pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
Aha. Now that makes sense. I missed that!

The previous guy obviously put both resistors on and that is what threw me off. Never asume anything they say - for good reason.

I am guessing that the <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>'s I have fitted will have blown then? My soldering is as good as any I have seen, so quite confident about that part. My last two <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP>'s. I'll order another one now and we'll see what comes of it in a couple of days. I will update then.

Voltage at pin 11 supposed to be zero? Obviously fitting a zero ohm <RESISTOR>R7249</RESISTOR> obviously shorts that to ground in effect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
That will not kill <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>.
VREG3 should get protected.
Put the last soldered <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> there.
If no short, try it.

Be aware, if DRVH1/2 are not properly soldered, <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR>/60 will blow.
Is better to check continuity...

Thanks very much for your help.It is much appreciated buddy.

OK. Another day another try.

Replaced  <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and also replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7261</TRANSISTOR> at the same time


[URL="https://store.rossmanngroup.com/d2-<CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>.html"]<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>[/URL] pin 22 is 1.2v
[URL="https://store.rossmanngroup.com/d2-<CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>.html"]<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>[/URL] pin 23 is 8.41v
[URL="https://store.rossmanngroup.com/d2-<CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>.html"]<CHIP>U7201</CHIP>[/URL] pin 12 is 3.37v

<CAPACITOR>C7205</CAPACITOR> is 0.77v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
If pins 23 & 12 have correct voltage (your case), you must get VREG3/5 & VREF2.
So check for any other "NO STUFF" mistake around.
Be sure <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and new MOSFETs are all correctly soldered.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2849</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> low
threads.message:
Everything is on correctly. That is the only thing I am sure of.

But like all boards where someone else has been playing beforehand, anything could be wrong. I am calling it a day on this board too.

I appreciate all YOUR help. I say yours as nobody else helped at all.

Maybe the forum would be better called then '2informaticos forum'.

Muchos Gracias Senior. Adios.
